etymologies: late 18th century; earliest use found in James Lee (1715–1795), nurseryman. From post-classical Latin runcinatus sawtoothed from classical Latin runcina carpenter's plane, but formerly taken to mean a saw (from Hellenistic Greek ῥυκάνη plane (from a first element of uncertain origin + -ανη, suffix forming nouns), with insertion of -n- apparently as a result of folk-etymological association with classical Latin runcāre to weed) + -ātus. Compare classical Latin runcināre to plane

definitions: Especially of a leaf: irregularly serrated, with the lobes or teeth curved toward the base.
